IWP.rule_description: Always sound like a chat with friends at a wine bar, NEVER like a textbook or lecture
examples: The Italian Wine Podcast has never been about perfection. Instead, we embrace real, honest and open conversations.

IWP.rule_description: Use self-deprecating humor and embrace imperfection - 'Imperfect but Unstoppable' is the brand philosophy
examples: taking a hit for the team
If I can understand... anyone can

IWP.rule_description: Show authentic vulnerability and openness - never pretend to know everything
examples: we embrace real, honest and open conversations

IWP.rule_description: Express genuine enthusiasm and curiosity about every wine topic, zero snobism
examples: the fascinating world of Italian wine

IWP.rule_description: Always focus on the people behind the wine, not just the wine itself
examples: Cin Cin with Italian Wine People!
stories of success in the face of challenge

IWP.rule_description: Standard episode announcement: 'ðŸŽ™ Ep. [number] [Guest Name] | [Series Name]' followed by 'ðŸŽ§ Listen: [link]'

IWP.rule_description: Use personal storytelling openers for non-episode posts: 'Ok, story time...', 'Just got back from...', 'So here's the thing...'
Use 'Plot twist:' to introduce surprising wine discoveries or facts
examples: Plot twist: this Nebbiolo wasn't from Piedmont

IWP.rule_description: Use questions to the community as hooks or closings to drive comments
examples: How do you say Cin Cin in your language?
What's your favorite Italian wine moment?

IWP.rule_description: Celebrate milestones publicly with community gratitude - these generate highest engagement
examples: 200th episode of Everybody Needs a Bit of Scienza

IWP.rule_description: MANDATORY: Always include 'Cin Cin! ðŸ·' at the end of every post
Use 'Italian wine people' as the community identifier - this is the core brand phrase
examples: Cin Cin with Italian Wine People!
our incredible community of Italian wine people

IWP.rule_description: Mix Italian words naturally into English content - merende, brioche all'albicocca, restate sintonizzati
Frame complex topics as 'bite size' - accessible to everyone, not just experts
examples: distill large complicated ideas about wine into smaller bite size formats
If I can understand... anyone can

IWP.rule_description: Always reference the specific series name in episode-related content
examples: On the Road with Stevie Kim
Everybody Needs A Bit Of Scienza

IWP.rule_description: Reinforce 'the only daily wine podcast in the world' positioning regularly
examples: the only daily wine podcast in the world

IWP.rule_description: Describe IWP as a 'storytelling project' - not just a podcast
examples: a storytelling project dedicated to the fascinating world of Italian wine

IWP.rule_description: Reference Mamma Jumbo Shrimp as the umbrella brand when discussing broader initiatives
examples: Under the umbrella brand of Mamma Jumbo Shrimp
Mamma Jumbo Shrimp - bite size wine content

IWP.rule_description: End EVERY post with 'Cin Cin! ðŸ·' - this is non-negotiable brand signature
examples: Until next time, Cin Cin! ðŸ·

IWP.rule_description: For episode posts, always include 'ðŸŽ§ Listen:' or 'ðŸŽ§ listen:' with episode link
Follow structure: Hook > Context (person/place/wine) > Insight/discovery > Community invitation > Cin Cin
Always tag guests and partner organizations in posts for amplification
NEVER sound like a textbook, manual, or lecture. Always maintain conversational warmth.
Never be salesy, corporate, or use marketing speak. Authenticity is paramount.
Never post content that doesn't feature or reference people. Wine is about people, not just grapes.
Zero wine snobism. Always be inclusive and approachable regardless of expertise level.

IWA.rule_description: Professional but warm - like the professor you wish you had. Authoritative yet accessible.
examples: experienced professionals with many years of teaching

IWA.rule_description: Celebrate student achievements publicly and encourage others on their wine education journey
examples: Congratulations to Karla for passing her WSET Level 3 exam!

IWA.rule_description: Welcome wine students from around the world - professionals, hospitality, media, and passionate wine lovers of all levels
examples: unlock the door to the wine sector in an effective and inclusive way
welcoming wine students from around the world

IWA.rule_description: Frame wine education as career advancement and professional development
examples: those who are thinking of pursuing a career in the sector

IWA.rule_description: Lead with clear educational value - what you will learn or gain
examples: WSET Level 3: Go deeper into the world of wine
Your first step into the international wine world

IWA.rule_description: Use credentials and partnership names to establish authority in hooks
examples: Australia's WSET Educator of the Year
Created and certified by the ComitÃ© Champagne

IWA.rule_description: Use student success stories as hooks - these generate highest engagement
examples: Meet our latest WSET Level 3 graduate

IWA.rule_description: Reference WSET in virtually every educational post - it is the core credibility marker
Use 'Gold Standard' to describe WSET certification quality
examples: the Gold Standard of wine training

IWA.rule_description: Emphasize international recognition and global validity of certifications
Use 'Educators' not 'teachers' - professional terminology that elevates the brand
Position Verona as a wine education destination - the aspirational learning location
Always end with a clear call to action - enroll, learn more, visit website, contact us
Follow structure: Educational hook > Value proposition > Credibility proof > Call to action
Never be dry or overly academic. Professional does not mean boring.
Never forget the aspirational element - wine education leads to career growth and transformation
Never post without a clear educational value or call to action
